<p><b>G.I. Joe</b> is a line of action figures produced by the <a href="/wiki/Toy" title="Toy">toy</a> company <a href="/wiki/Hasbro" title="Hasbro">Hasbro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> The initial product offering represented four of the branches of the <a href="/wiki/U.S._armed_forces" title="U.S. armed forces" class="mw-redirect">U.S. armed forces</a> with the Action Soldier (<a href="/wiki/U.S._Army" title="U.S. Army" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Army</a>), Action Sailor (<a href="/wiki/U.S._Navy" title="U.S. Navy" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Navy</a>), Action Pilot (<a href="/wiki/USAF" title="USAF" class="mw-redirect">USAF</a>), Action Marine (<a href="/wiki/USMC" title="USMC" class="mw-redirect">USMC</a>) and later on, the Action Nurse. The term <a href="/wiki/G.I._(military)" title="G.I. (military)">G.I.</a> stands, in popular usage, for Government Issued<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> and after the First World War became a generic term for U.S. soldiers. The origin of the term dates to World War I, when much of the equipment issued to U.S. soldiers was stamped "G.I.", meaning that it was made from <a href="/wiki/Galvanized_iron" title="Galvanized iron" class="mw-redirect">galvanized iron</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rawson_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rawson-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wordorig_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wordorig-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> The development of G.I. Joe led to the coining of the term "<a href="/wiki/Action_figure" title="Action figure">action figure</a>". G.I. Joe's appeal to children has made it an American icon among toys.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>The G.I. Joe trademark has been used by Hasbro to title two different toy lines. The original 12-inch line that began in 1964 centered on realistic action figures. In the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, this line was licensed to <a href="/wiki/Palitoy" title="Palitoy">Palitoy</a> and known as <a href="/wiki/Action_Man" title="Action Man">Action Man</a>. In 1982, the line was relaunched in a 3?-inch scale complete with vehicles, playsets, and a complex background story involving an ongoing struggle between the <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_Team" title="G.I. Joe Team">G.I. Joe Team</a> and the evil <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Command" title="Cobra Command">Cobra Command</a> which seeks to take over the Free World through terrorism. As the American line evolved into the <a href="/wiki/Real_American_Hero" title="Real American Hero" class="mw-redirect">Real American Hero</a> series, Action Man also changed, by using the same molds and being renamed as <a href="/wiki/Action_Force" title="Action Force">Action Force</a>. Although the members of the G.I. Joe team are not <a href="/wiki/Superheroes" title="Superheroes" class="mw-redirect">superheroes</a>, they all had expertise in areas such as martial arts, weapons and explosives.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>G.I. Joe was inducted into the <a href="/wiki/National_Toy_Hall_of_Fame" title="National Toy Hall of Fame">National Toy Hall of Fame</a> at <a href="/wiki/The_Strong" title="The Strong">The Strong</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rochester,_New_York" title="Rochester, New York">Rochester, New York</a>, in 2003.</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_the_12_in._figures">History of the 12 in. figures</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History of the 12 in. figures">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a href="/wiki/File:GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/24/GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg/250px-GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg" width="250" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/24/GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg/375px-GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/24/GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg/500px-GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:GIJoe_OriginalLineup.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Original G.I. Joe lineup.</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="America.27s_movable_fighting_man_.281964.E2.80.931969.29">America's movable fighting man (1964每1969)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: America's movable fighting man (1964每1969)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_America%27s_movable_fighting_man" title="G.I. Joe: America's movable fighting man">G.I. Joe: America's movable fighting man</a></div>
<p>The conventional marketing wisdom of the early 1960s was that boys would not play with dolls, thus the word "doll" was never used by Hasbro or anyone involved in the development or marketing of G.I. Joe. "Action figure" was the only acceptable term, and has since become the generic description for any poseable doll intended for boys. "America's movable fighting man" is a registered trademark of Hasbro, and was prominently displayed on every boxed figure package.</p>
<p>The Hasbro prototypes were originally named "Rocky" (marine/soldier) "Skip" (sailor) and "Ace" (pilot), before the more universal name G.I. Joe was adopted. One of the prototypes would later sell in a <a href="/wiki/Heritage_Auctions" title="Heritage Auctions">Heritage</a> auction in 2003 for $200,001.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Aside from the obvious trademarking on the right buttock, other aspects of the figure were copyrighted features that allowed Hasbro to successfully pursue cases against producers of cheap imitations, since the human figure itself cannot be copyrighted or trademarked. The scar on the right cheek was one; another, unintentional at first, was the <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_America%27s_movable_fighting_man#Trademarks_and_Copyrights" title="G.I. Joe: America's movable fighting man">placement of the right thumbnail on the underside of the thumb</a>. Early trademarking, with "G.I. Joe?", was used through some point in 1965; the markings changed once G.I. Joe was a registered trademark; "G.I. Joe?" now appears on the first line. Subsequently, the stamped trademarking was altered after the patent was granted (in late 1966), and assigned a number; 3,277,602. Figures with this marking would have entered the retail market during 1967.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Adventure_Team_.281970.E2.80.931976.29">Adventure Team (1970每1976)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Adventure Team (1970每1976)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_Adventure_Team" title="G.I. Joe Adventure Team">G.I. Joe Adventure Team</a></div>
<p>By the late 1960s, in the wake of the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, Hasbro sought to downplay the war theme that had initially defined "G.I. Joe". The line became known as "The Adventures of G.I. Joe". In 1970, Hasbro settled on the name "Adventure Team". Highlights of the line included:</p>
<ul>
<li>To coincide with the new direction, "Life-Like" flocked hair and beard, an innovation developed in England by <a href="/wiki/Palitoy" title="Palitoy">Palitoy</a> for their licensed version of Joe, <a href="/wiki/Action_Man" title="Action Man">Action Man</a>, is introduced in 1970. A retooled African American Adventurer was also introduced, which came in two versions as did the others in the series, bearded or shaven.<sup id="cite_ref-Thelife_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thelife-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In 1974, named after the increasingly popular martial art, Hasbro introduced "Kung-Fu Grip" to the G.I. Joe line. This was another innovation that had been developed in the UK for Action Man. The hands were molded in a softer plastic that allowed the fingers to grip objects in a more lifelike fashion.</li>
<li>In 1976, G.I. Joe was given eagle eye vision; a movable eye mechanism to allow the toy to appear to be looking around when a lever in the back of the head was moved. This would be the last major innovation for the original line of 12-inch figures.</li>
</ul>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MikePower.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d2/MikePower.jpg/150px-MikePower.jpg" width="150" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d2/MikePower.jpg/225px-MikePower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/d2/MikePower.jpg 2x" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MikePower.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"><img src="//bits.wikimedia.org/static-1.22wmf21/skins/common/images/magnify-clip.png" width="15" height="11" alt="" /></a></div>
Mike Power, Atomic Man</div>
</div>
</div>
<dl>
<dt>A shift in play patterns</dt>
</dl>
<p>For its first ten years, G.I. Joe was a generic soldier/adventurer with only the slightest hints of a team concept existing. In 1975, after a failed bid to purchase the toy rights to the <a href="/wiki/Six_Million_Dollar_Man" title="Six Million Dollar Man" class="mw-redirect">Six Million Dollar Man</a>, Hasbro issued a bionic warrior figure named "Mike Power, Atomic Man", which sold over one million units. Also added to the Adventure Team was a super-hero, "Bullet Man", and the character gained recurring enemies, called "The Intruders 每 Strongmen from Another World".<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Comics included with figures at the time featured "Eagle Eye" Joe, Atomic Man, and Bullet Man operating together. The Adventure Team was finally an actual team. The original 12-inch G.I. Joe line ended in America in 1976. At this time, Hasbro released a line of inexpensive, rotationally-molded mannequins in the G.I. Joe style called "The Defenders".</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International_G.I._Joe_licensees">International G.I. Joe licensees</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: International G.I. Joe licensees">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Action_Man" title="Action Man">Action Man</a> and <a href="/wiki/Action_Force" title="Action Force">Action Force</a></div>
<p>From 1966 through 1984, Palitoy Ltd. produced a British version of the 12-inch G.I. Joe line, under the <a href="/wiki/Action_Man" title="Action Man">Action Man</a> name for the UK market. Initially, these were exactly the same designs as the American figures, and at first the same military theme which included figures from <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. The line later expanded the line to include all men of action, like <a href="/wiki/Soccer" title="Soccer" class="mw-redirect">football</a> players and other sports figures. In the early 1980s, Palitoy responded to falling sales of Action Man by launching "Action Force", a new range of smaller military-themed figures in the style of the then-popular Star Wars line from Kenner. Later, when the U.S. Real American Hero line was released in the UK, they were released under the '<a href="/wiki/Action_Force" title="Action Force">Action Force</a>' title, since the term "G.I." is not in common use in Britain. The figures had the same appearance and code names as the American G.I. Joes, but their identities and histories were international rather than purely American or British. The range was later renamed G.I. Joe to bring it into line with international markets; however, the Action Man line retained its original name when it was revived in the early 1990s.</p>
<p>The G.I. Joe line was also licensed to <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> under the Action Team name. In <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geyperman" title="Geyperman">Geyperman</a> was the Hasbro licensee, although the products were more based on Palitoy's line, down to the logo design. In France the name was Action Joe, in <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, Takara and Tsukuda licensed the figures under the names "G.I. Joe" and "Combat Man". In Italy, Polistil licensed the figures under the Action Team name (same as they were called in Germany). In <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, the line was released as "G.I. Joe" by Kenbrite; Palitoy also licensed their "ActionMan" line to TolToys, now Hasbro is producing G.I. Joe figures in Australia under the name "Falcon" and the 3?" figures under the name "Comandos em A??o". In <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, it was licensed to Brinquedos Estrela; the 12" line was called "Falcon" and the 3?" figures were called "Comandos em A??o" ("Action Commandos"). In <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, the G.I. Joe figures were licensed by Veri-li enterprises under the name "Joe Super Temerario", and "Los Temerarios". The G.I. Joe toy line was produced in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> under the Funskool brand.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_the_3.75.22_figures">History of the 3.75" figures</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: History of the 3.75&quot; figures">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="A_Real_American_Hero_.281982.E2.80.931994.29">A Real American Hero (1982每1994)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: A Real American Hero (1982每1994)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero">G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero</a></div>
<p>The year 1982 saw the highly successful relaunch of the G.I. Joe product line in a smaller, 3?-inch scale, of the same type employed by the wildly popular <a href="/wiki/Star_Wars" title="Star Wars">Star Wars</a> figures, but with many more points of articulation. The 1982 relaunch pioneered several tactics in toy marketing, combining traditional advertising with an <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero_(1985_TV_series)" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero (1985 TV series)">animated television mini-series</a> and an <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero_(Marvel_Comics)" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero (Marvel Comics)">ongoing comic book</a>. The decision to use a smaller 3?-inch scale for the figures also made it possible for Hasbro to produce a variety of matching vehicles and playsets that further expanded the appeal and commercial potential of the line.</p>
<p>G.I. Joe's increasing popularity supported an array of spin-off merchandising that included <a href="/wiki/Poster" title="Poster">posters</a>, <a href="/wiki/T-shirt" title="T-shirt">t-shirts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">video games</a>, <a href="/wiki/Board_game" title="Board game">board games</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kite_flying" title="Kite flying" class="mw-redirect">kites</a>. In 1985, both <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Toy_%26_Lamp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toy &amp; Lamp (page does not exist)">Toy &amp; Lamp</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hobby_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hobby World (page does not exist)">Hobby World</a></i> magazines ranked <i>G.I. Joe</i> as the top-selling American toy.</p>
<p>The 3?&#160;inch line was canceled at the end of 1994. This was also the 30th Anniversary of G.I. Joe and accordingly, Hasbro released a series of 12-inch and 3?&#160;inch figures based on the Original Action Team figures from 1964.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Stars_.26_Stripes_Forever_.E2.80.93_TRU_Exclusives_.281997.E2.80.931998.29">Stars &amp; Stripes Forever 每 TRU Exclusives (1997每1998)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Stars &amp; Stripes Forever 每 TRU Exclusives (1997每1998)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>A select assortment of figures from the "Real American Hero" line were released as Toys "R" Us exclusives to celebrate the 15th anniversary. A second assortment followed in 1998.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="A_Real_American_Hero_Collection_.282000.E2.80.932002.29">A Real American Hero Collection (2000每2002)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: A Real American Hero Collection (2000每2002)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2000, Hasbro re-released a selection of 3?" G.I. Joe figures and vehicles. This line lasted until 2002. The figures were sold in packs of two and consisted of repainted versions of figures from the Real American Hero line. Some of these repainted figures were assigned new identities: for example, the Baroness figure was repainted and sold as a new character called <a href="/wiki/Chameleon_(G.I._Joe)" title="Chameleon (G.I. Joe)" class="mw-redirect">Chameleon</a>, described on the packaging as "the illegitimate half sister of Baroness".<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="G.I._Joe_vs_Cobra_.282002.E2.80.932005.29">G.I. Joe vs Cobra (2002每2005)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: G.I. Joe vs Cobra (2002每2005)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_vs._Cobra" title="G.I. Joe vs. Cobra">G.I. Joe vs. Cobra</a></div>
<p>Beginning in 2002, newly designed collections of 3?" G.I. Joe figures and vehicles were released. Each collection centered on a storyline or theme, such as "Spy Troops" and "Valor vs. Venom".<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>Direct-to-<a href="/wiki/DVD" title="DVD">DVD</a> features were animated for both the <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Spy_Troops" title="G.I. Joe: Spy Troops">G.I. Joe: Spy Troops</a> and <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Valor_vs._Venom" title="G.I. Joe: Valor vs. Venom">G.I. Joe: Valor vs. Venom</a> collections, as well as a new trading card game based on the G.I. Joe vs. Cobra storyline. Both the 12" and 3?" lines were put on hiatus prior to the release of the Sigma 6 line in 2005.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Direct_to_Consumer_.28DTC.29_.282005.E2.80.932006.29">Direct to Consumer (DTC) (2005每2006)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Direct to Consumer (DTC) (2005每2006)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The 3?" line was reintroduced after a very brief hiatus via Hasbro's direct-to-consumer website HasbroToyShop.com and various online retailers. As a result of the line's success, some figures also became available at certain retailers, such as <a href="/wiki/Toys_%22R%22_Us" title="Toys &quot;R&quot; Us">Toys "R" Us</a>.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="25th_Anniversary_.282007.E2.80.932009.29">25th Anniversary (2007每2009)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: 25th Anniversary (2007每2009)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero_25th_Anniversary" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero 25th Anniversary">G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero 25th Anniversary</a></div>
<p>2007 marked the 25th anniversary of the "Real American Hero" line. To commemorate the event, Hasbro released a "25th Anniversary" collection of newly sculpted 4" figures (as opposed to the 3?" scale of the RAH line) based on classic and new designs of many of the line's best known and most popular characters. The 25th Anniversary figures replaced the classic O-ring construction with a swivel chest feature and increased points of articulation beyond the standard shoulder, elbow and knees to swivel wrists, ankles and double-hinged knees. The 25th anniversary figures also include "<a href="/wiki/Specialist_Trakker" title="Specialist Trakker" class="mw-redirect">Specialist Trakker</a>", otherwise known as Matt Trakker the leader of <a href="/wiki/M.A.S.K." title="M.A.S.K.">M.A.S.K.</a> <sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>Originally planned to consist of only two sets of five figures each (one G.I. Joe and one Cobra), the 25th Anniversary collection was well received by retailers and collectors and has since been expanded by Hasbro into a full-fledged toyline to run through 2009. The most recent releases in this line do not include the "25th Anniversary" branding, but in all other respects constitute a continuation of the 25th Anniversary collection. Other waves set to be released in 2009 include the <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Resolute" title="G.I. Joe: Resolute">Resolute</a> figures, which were introduced in wave 13, and had an animated feature premiere in April 2009.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>The "25th Anniversary" line was later canceled, in favor of releasing figures for the upcoming live action movie. The some of the planned figures from canceled waves, totaling 14 figures, were instead released as two 7-figure exclusive packs. Entitled "Defense and Attack of Cobra Island," each set contained figures from one opposing side<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. The canceled future waves included Night Force Falcon, the Python Patrol Trooper and Tele-Viper, and an Iron Klaw/Resolute Crimson Guard Trooper Comic Pack.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Rise_of_Cobra_.282009.29">The Rise of Cobra (2009)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: The Rise of Cobra (2009)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In July 2009, a series of figures based on the <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Rise_of_Cobra" title="G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra">G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra</a></i> movie was released in the United States and Australia. The Line was a mixture of the Rise of Cobra movie designs and some G.I. Joe vs Cobra designs and a some 25th Action figure molds and new molds.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Pursuit_of_Cobra_.282010.E2.80.932011.29">The Pursuit of Cobra (2010每2011)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: The Pursuit of Cobra (2010每2011)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2010, a new series of figures was released, based on four battlegrounds: Desert, City, Jungle and Arctic. The packaging was an update to the 25th Anniversary design, featuring cues to the vintage era as well as a modern look. Also, the figures had non-actor based heads.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="30th_Anniversary_.282011.E2.80.932012.29">30th Anniversary (2011每2012)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: 30th Anniversary (2011每2012)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2011, a new series of figures has been released, including characters from both G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero and the <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Renegades" title="G.I. Joe: Renegades">G.I. Joe: Renegades</a></i> cartoon series. This series was continued through 2012.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Retaliation_.282013.29">Retaliation (2013)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Retaliation (2013)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>A series of figures based on the movie <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Retaliation" title="G.I. Joe: Retaliation">G.I. Joe: Retaliation</a></i> was confirmed by Hasbro in February 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup> Despite the movie's release being moved from June 2012 to March 2013, the initial assortments of figures, vehicles, and role-play items were shipped to retailers, and appeared on store shelves in May 2012. A <i>Variety</i> article was published stating that the already released figures had been pulled from the shelves and recalled by Hasbro,<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup> although the companies official statement indicated that existing product would be sold through. New product shipments were halted by Hasbro, but existing Retaliation figures were available in Target, Wal-Mart, and Toys R Us as late as December 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>13<span>]</span></a></sup> The toyline was re-released in the United States in February 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Return_of_the_12-inch_G.I._Joe_.281991.E2.80.932005.29">Return of the 12-inch G.I. Joe (1991每2005)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Return of the 12-inch G.I. Joe (1991每2005)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Hasbro began releasing new 12-inch G.I. Joe figures in 1991. The first figure, <a href="/wiki/Duke_(G.I._Joe)" title="Duke (G.I. Joe)">Duke</a>, was marketed exclusively to <a href="/wiki/Target_Corporation" title="Target Corporation">Target</a> retail stores.<sup id="cite_ref-30thAnnPg129_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30thAnnPg129-15"><span>[</span>15<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hall_of_Fame_.281992.E2.80.931994.29">Hall of Fame (1992每1994)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Hall of Fame (1992每1994)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Hall_of_Fame" title="G.I. Joe: Hall of Fame">G.I. Joe: Hall of Fame</a></div>
<p>Based on the Real American Hero toyline, the Hall of Fame series featured Mission Gear Outfits, vehicles, and featured popular characters like Snake-Eyes, Stalker, Gung-Ho, Cobra Commander, Destro, and Storm Shadow among others.</p>
<p>This was followed by an anniversary series based on the 1960s line〞and was followed by the Hall of Fame Limited Editions, also based on 60s releases.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classic_Collection_.281995.E2.80.932004.29">Classic Collection (1995每2004)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Classic Collection (1995每2004)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_Classic_Collection" title="G.I. Joe Classic Collection" class="mw-redirect">G.I. Joe Classic Collection</a></div>
<p>G.I. Janes were introduced in a series called the Classic Collection, the first 12-inch female dolls in the G.I. Joe line-up since 1967; this doll was a <a href="/wiki/Helicopter" title="Helicopter">helicopter</a> pilot. The Classic Collection hearkened back to the original all military theme of G.I. Joe with fairly realistic uniforms and gear. Soldiers from Australia, Britain, and other nations, as well as United States forces were featured. The line also presented an all-new articulated G.I. Joe figure that formed the basis of many offerings until the 12" line was discontinued in the new millennium.</p>
<p>In 2000, a <i><a href="/wiki/Navajo_Nation" title="Navajo Nation">Navajo</a> <a href="/wiki/Codetalkers" title="Codetalkers" class="mw-redirect">Code Talker</a></i> was introduced, one of only two 12-inch G.I. Joe talking figures (until this time) since the 1970s.</p>
<p>In 2001, G.I. Joe honored the events of the 1941 <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a> by releasing a line of Pearl Harbor figures. In 2003 Hasbro announced the release of the 40th Anniversary G.I. Joe line. This line featured reproductions of the earliest G.I. Joe figures and accessories originally made in 1964.</p>
<p>In November 2006 a reproduction Land Adventurer G.I. Joe figure was released as an exclusive to Hot Topic stores. The figure was a reproduction of the Land Adventurer with the Kung Fu Grip and came in the "Coffin" style box. A reproduction Talking Adventure Team Commander was also released in a limited run of 1,970 issues.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Masterpiece_.281996.E2.80.931997.29">Masterpiece (1996每1997)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Masterpiece (1996每1997)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Masterpiece_Edition" title="G.I. Joe: Masterpiece Edition">G.I. Joe: Masterpiece Edition</a></div>
<p>In 1997, the original G.I. Joe figure returned via the G.I. Joe Masterpiece Edition, a unique book-and-figure product created by <a href="/wiki/Chronicle_Books" title="Chronicle Books">Chronicle Books</a> with assistance from Don Levine, former creative director of Hasbro Toys and the driving force behind the original Joe concept.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Timeless_Collection_.281998.E2.80.932003.29">Timeless Collection (1998每2003)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Timeless Collection (1998每2003)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Timeless_Collection" title="G.I. Joe: Timeless Collection">G.I. Joe: Timeless Collection</a></div>
<p>During the late 1990s Hasbro built on the renewed interest in authentic reproductions of G.I. Joe established by the Masterpiece Edition reproduction book/figure set; they bought the rights to the ME figure and released a range of store exclusive reproduction figure sets, with the character of the sixties G.I. Joe boxed sets.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_licensees">Other licensees</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Other licensees">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Super_Joe_.281977.E2.80.931978.29">Super Joe (1977每1978)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Super Joe (1977每1978)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1977, Hasbro released the Super Joe Adventure Team, and took the battle between good and evil to the stars. The figures were scaled down to 8?&#160;inches, similar in size to <a href="/wiki/Mego_Corporation" title="Mego Corporation">Mego</a>'s Superheroes line of action figures. The line was a hybrid of superhero and space action figures with new features incorporated such as battery powered back-pack lights and motorized accessories. The hero Super Joe characters, Super Joe Commander (Caucasian/African American) and Super Joe (Caucasian/African American) had a "One-Two Punch" that could be activated by pressing panels on the figure's back. The majority of these figures used Kung-Fu grip style plastic in the joints and hands. Unfortunately, with age, the material degrades, leaving even unopened figures missing limbs and hands.</p>
<p>Unlike the original G.I. Joe collection, the Super Joe collection was developed from the start with a play-pattern of Good vs Evil. Super Joe Commander and the Adventure Team (Man of Action, and Adventurer) with their alien comrades "The Night Fighters," Luminos and The Shield, fight against the evil Gor, King of the Terrons, Terron, The Beast from Beyond, and his orange-eyed ally Darkon, the half-man half-monster.</p>
<p>Super Joe was discontinued by the end of 1978. The same basic body molds were used later by a subsidiary of <a href="/wiki/Hasbro" title="Hasbro">Hasbro</a> to produce a line of action figures based on the TV series <i><a href="/wiki/Space_Academy" title="Space Academy">Space Academy</a>.</i></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Short-lived_lines_.281994.E2.80.931997.29">Short-lived lines (1994每1997)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Short-lived lines (1994每1997)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>As a follow-up to the Real American Hero toyline, <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Savage_and_his_Screaming_Eagles" title="Sgt. Savage and his Screaming Eagles">Sgt. Savage and his Screaming Eagles</a></i> figures debuted in late 1994. It was canceled after only two waves of figures were released, due to a combination of scarce marketing and, therefore, low sales.</p>
<p>In 1995, <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_Extreme" title="G.I. Joe Extreme">G.I. Joe Extreme</a></i> figures were introduced by <a href="/wiki/Kenner_Toys" title="Kenner Toys" class="mw-redirect">Kenner Toys</a> (who had merged with Hasbro in late 1994, taking over their boys toys production). Along with the release of toys, G.I. Joe Extreme featured a comic book, published by <a href="/wiki/Dark_Horse_Comics" title="Dark Horse Comics">Dark Horse Comics</a>, and a Gunther-Wahl-produced cartoon series which ran for two seasons.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sigma_6_.282005.E2.80.932007.29">Sigma 6 (2005每2007)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Sigma 6 (2005每2007)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Sigma_6" title="G.I. Joe: Sigma 6">G.I. Joe: Sigma 6</a></div>
<p>2005 saw the introduction of a new line called <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Sigma_6" title="G.I. Joe: Sigma 6">G.I. Joe: Sigma 6</a></i>, consisting initially of an 8" scale selection of action figures distinguished by their extensive articulation and accessories. Sigma 6 combined entirely new characters with already familiar characters from the 3?" "Real American Hero" line. Its release was accompanied by a television series produced by the <a href="/wiki/Anime" title="Anime">Japanese animation</a> studio <a href="/wiki/GONZO" title="GONZO" class="mw-redirect">GONZO</a>, and a comic book mini-series published by Devil's Due. Hasbro also expanded the Sigma 6 line to include a 2?" scale selection of vehicles, play sets, and figurines with limited articulation.</p>
<p>2007 saw the re-branding of the 8" line. The <i>Sigma Six</i> branding was dropped in the spring of 2007. Subsequent 8" figures were branded simply as "G.I. Joe" action figures and divided into differently packaged sub-groups such as <i>Combat Squad</i>, <i>Commandos</i>, and <i>Adventure Team</i>. The entire 8" product line was canceled by the end of 2007, although Hasbro considers the 8" figures a success and may revisit the scale in the future.<sup class="Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2009)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sideshow_Collectibles_.282009.E2.80.93present.29">Sideshow Collectibles (2009每present)</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Sideshow Collectibles (2009每present)">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 2009, <a href="/wiki/Sideshow_Collectibles" title="Sideshow Collectibles">Sideshow Collectibles</a> began releasing its own line of G.I. Joe figures under license from Hasbro. These highly-detailed figures offer new looks at key characters. In addition, Sideshow also created "Figure Environments", which were small diorama pieces intended to enhance the display of their figures.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> A line of figures was featured at Comic-Con 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span>[</span>18<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Real_people_honored_with_G.I._Joe_figures">Real people honored with <i>G.I. Joe</i> figures</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Real people honored with G.I. Joe figures">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_real_people_honored_with_G.I._Joe_figures" title="List of real people honored with G.I. Joe figures" class="mw-redirect">List of real people honored with G.I. Joe figures</a></div>
<p>The G.I. Joe brand has made <a href="/wiki/Promotion_(marketing)" title="Promotion (marketing)">promotional</a> action figures based on real-life persons, both military and civilian, that the company deems <i>Real American Heroes</i>.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_media">Other media</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Other media">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Comics">Comics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Comics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_(comics)" title="G.I. Joe (comics)">G.I. Joe (comics)</a></div>
<p>G.I. Joe originated from a comic strip in the 1940s called "Private Breger".<sup id="cite_ref-Thelife_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thelife-9"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup> G.I. Joe re-appeared in the 1980s as a promotional comic book, produced by <a href="/wiki/Marvel_Comics" title="Marvel Comics">Marvel Comics</a>. The success of the main title lead Marvel Comics to produce a secondary title, <i>G.I. Joe: Special Missions</i> which lasted 28 issues. The main series released its final issue #155 in December 1994, coinciding with the end of the <i>Real American Hero</i> toy line.</p>
<p>In July 2001, <a href="/wiki/Devil%27s_Due_Publishing" title="Devil's Due Publishing">Devil's Due Publishing</a> acquired the rights to <i>G.I. Joe</i> and released a four-issue limited series entitled <i>G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero (Reinstated)</i>. The new series picked up seven years after the end of the Marvel Comics series, and also used elements from the animated TV series. Strong sales led to <i>Reinstated</i> being upgraded to ongoing, and DDP also published other <i>G.I. Joe</i> titles outside the existing continuity. DDP's license with Hasbro expired in 2008 and was not renewed.</p>
<p>In 2009, <a href="/wiki/IDW_Publishing" title="IDW Publishing">IDW Publishing</a> began to publish the series again. IDW's G.I. Joe series is a complete reboot of the property, ignoring the continuity from the Marvel and Devil's Due incarnations of the comic. However, the <i>G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero</i> series originally published by Marvel Comics in the 1980s and 1990s was revived as an ongoing series in May 2010 with a special #155 ? issue, and followed by #156 onwards in July 2010. The series directly picks up from the end of the Marvel Comics series and ignores the Devil's Due continuity completely.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cartoon">Cartoon</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Cartoon">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_(disambiguation)#Television" title="G.I. Joe (disambiguation)">G.I. Joe (disambiguation)#Television</a></div>
<p>The premise of the <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero_(1985_TV_series)" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero (1985 TV series)">1985 cartoon series</a> was "good vs. evil". The show's opening theme song included the narration: "G.I. Joe is the code name for America's daring, highly trained special mission force. Its purpose: to defend human freedom against <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Command" title="Cobra Command">Cobra</a>, a ruthless <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorist</a> organization determined to rule the world."<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<p>The show featured physical fighting and high-tech weapons as a way to compensate for toned-down violence and lack of bullets in what was intended to be children's program. The show also featured <a href="/wiki/Public_service_announcement" title="Public service announcement">public service announcements</a> placed at the end of each show. These PSAs ended with the phrase: "Now you know, and knowing is half the battle."<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup> The series ran for a total of 95 episodes, from 1985 to 1986.</p>
<p>The animated series was canceled after the release of <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Movie" title="G.I. Joe: The Movie">G.I. Joe: The Movie</a></i>, but made a significant return in 1989, with the animation company <a href="/wiki/DiC" title="DiC" class="mw-redirect">DiC</a> taking over where <a href="/wiki/Sunbow" title="Sunbow">Sunbow</a>/<a href="/wiki/Marvel_Animation" title="Marvel Animation">Marvel</a> left off. That year, DiC released a 5 part mini-series entitled "Operation: Dragonfire", in which the Joes faced off once again against Cobra as they tried to take control of an energy source known only as 'dragonfire.' In this mini-series, <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Commander" title="Cobra Commander">Cobra Commander</a> was also returned to a semi-human state by the energy itself while <a href="/wiki/Serpentor" title="Serpentor">Serpentor</a>, the Cobra emperor, was turned into an iguana by the dragonfire. <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero_(1989_TV_series)" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero (1989 TV series)">The animated series</a> proved to be a bit of a success as DIC made 2 more seasons (1990每91); however, the series ended after 1991.</p>
<p>Following the "Operation: Dragonfire" series was the "<a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_Extreme" title="G.I. Joe Extreme">G.I. Joe Extreme</a>" series in 1995 created by <a href="/wiki/Sunbow_Productions" title="Sunbow Productions" class="mw-redirect">Sunbow Productions</a>. This new animated series was based upon the G.I. Joe Extreme toy line. This series was canceled after 2 seasons (1995每97), along with the toy line.</p>
<p>G.I. Joe had no series on the air until its resurgence in the 2000's which accompanied a new interest in the Real American Hero toy line, and new lines including <i><a href="/wiki/Spy_Troops" title="Spy Troops" class="mw-redirect">Spy Troops</a></i> (2003), <i><a href="/wiki/Valor_vs._Venom" title="Valor vs. Venom" class="mw-redirect">Valor vs. Venom</a></i> (2004), and <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Sigma_6" title="G.I. Joe: Sigma 6">Sigma 6</a></i> (2005-2007). This short-lived series was followed by <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Resolute" title="G.I. Joe: Resolute">G.I. Joe: Resolute</a></i> (2008), which was originally released as mini webisodes, with the full series later broadcast on <a href="/wiki/Cartoon_Network" title="Cartoon Network">Cartoon Network</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Adult_Swim" title="Adult Swim">Adult Swim</a>. This new series was more realistic and contained graphic violence and dark themes, with Cobra portrayed as a serious threat, which was different from the original and preceding series. In 2010, <a href="/wiki/The_Hub_(TV_channel)" title="The Hub (TV channel)" class="mw-redirect">The Hub</a> launched <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Renegades" title="G.I. Joe: Renegades">G.I. Joe: Renegades</a></i>, in which the Joes became fugitives seeking to clear their names and Cobra worked towards world domination under the guise of a pharmaceutical company.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Film">Film</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Film">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_(disambiguation)#Films" title="G.I. Joe (disambiguation)">G.I. Joe (disambiguation)#Films</a></div>
<p>Many movies have been made based upon G.I. Joe and the toy lines that developed from the action figure. The <i>G.I. Joe: Real American Hero</i> cartoon series was followed up by <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Movie" title="G.I. Joe: The Movie">G.I. Joe: The Movie</a></i>. The film had been released direct-to-video in 1987 because of the perceived box office failure of another animated movie 每 <i>The Transformers: The Movie</i>. Inspired by viewers' reaction to Optimus Prime's death, <i>G.I. Joe: The Movie</i> was re-dubbed, cutting out the death of one of the main characters, <a href="/wiki/Duke_(G.I._Joe)" title="Duke (G.I. Joe)">Duke</a>. Instead, he falls into a coma and recovers (unseen) at the movie's end. Also, the main villain, Cobra Commander, met his own demise when he was turned into a living snake by mutant spores created by a new enemy, Cobra-la.</p>
<p>A direct to video animated series was created for the Sgt. Savage line, packaged with an exclusive Sgt. Savage figure in 1994. Next in the G.I. Joe based line of movies was the 2003 release of <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Spy_Troops" title="G.I. Joe: Spy Troops">Spy Troops: The Movie</a></i>, Hasbro's first computer animated feature which coincided with the release of its "Spy Troops" header line. Next followed <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Valor_vs._Venom" title="G.I. Joe: Valor vs. Venom">Valor vs. Venom</a></i> (2004), in response to sales from "Spy Troops". This was Hasbro's second commissioned feature using computer graphics to coincide with the line of the same name. By 2005, Hasbro had entered into an exclusive agreement with Paramount Pictures to have them distribute any future, features based on the "Real American Heroes" line, but by the time a third movie was to be created, this time called, <i>Attack of the BATS</i>, Hasbro's sales on the "Real American Heroes" line had once again slumped, and the project was scrapped.</p>
<p>In 2009 <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Sommers" title="Stephen Sommers">Stephen Sommers</a> directed a big budget Hollywood live-action movie based on G.I. Joe. The first film in what is intended to be a franchise, is <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Rise_of_Cobra" title="G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra">G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra</a></i>, stars <a href="/wiki/Channing_Tatum" title="Channing Tatum">Channing Tatum</a> in the role of Duke, and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Gordon-Levitt" title="Joseph Gordon-Levitt">Joseph Gordon-Levitt</a> in the role of <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Commander" title="Cobra Commander">Cobra Commander</a>. Tatum describes the film as being a cross between <a href="/wiki/X-Men" title="X-Men">X-Men</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transformers" title="Transformers">Transformers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mission_Impossible" title="Mission Impossible" class="mw-redirect">Mission Impossible</a>, "It's a huge $170 million movie. It's just a big kid sort of driven film."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> The movie showcased the main members of G.I. Joe and Cobra. While some characters held true to the cartoon adaptations, others differed markedly in significant respects. As well, the storyline gave a different foundation for the battle between G.I. Joe and Cobra. The movie is based in present time (however at the beginning of the movie it states "In the not too distant future") and shows glimpses of each character＊s history. In the movie, Cobra sets out to cause destruction using high tech weapons and sell them to ruthless terrorists. The G.I. Joe members join together to stop Cobra from becoming a global terrorist organization.</p>
<p>To promote the film, <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Invasion_of_Cobra_Island" title="G.I. Joe: The Invasion of Cobra Island" class="mw-redirect">G.I. Joe: The Invasion of Cobra Island</a></i> was produced as a viral campaign. The short animated two-parter used stop motion and puppet animation utilizing Hasbro's toy line, and was produced by R.M. Productions Ltd.</p>
<p>The sequel <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Retaliation" title="G.I. Joe: Retaliation">G.I. Joe: Retaliation</a></i> was scheduled to be released in June 2012 but was delayed until March 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> In the film, the Joes are framed as traitors by <a href="/wiki/Zartan" title="Zartan">Zartan</a>, who is still impersonating the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Commander" title="Cobra Commander">Cobra Commander</a> now has all the world leaders under <a href="/wiki/Cobra_Command" title="Cobra Command">Cobra</a>'s control, with their advanced warheads aimed at innocent populaces around the world. Outnumbered and out gunned, the Joes form a plan with the original G.I. Joe <a href="/wiki/General_Joseph_Colton" title="General Joseph Colton">General Joseph Colton</a> to overthrow the Cobra Commander and his allies Zartan, <a href="/wiki/Storm_Shadow_(G.I._Joe)" title="Storm Shadow (G.I. Joe)">Storm Shadow</a> and <a href="/wiki/Firefly_(G.I._Joe)" title="Firefly (G.I. Joe)">Firefly</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-04:24_PM_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-04:24_PM-24"><span>[</span>24<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">Video games</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=G.I._Joe&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Video games">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_G.I._Joe_video_games" title="List of G.I. Joe video games">List of G.I. Joe video games</a></div>
<p>There were several <a href="/wiki/Video_game" title="Video game">video game</a> adaptations of G.I. Joe, including <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_Cobra_Strike" title="G.I. Joe: Cobra Strike">G.I. Joe: Cobra Strike</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Parker_Brothers" title="Parker Brothers">Parker Brothers</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Atari_2600" title="Atari 2600">Atari 2600</a> and <a href="/wiki/Intellivision" title="Intellivision">Intellivision</a> (1983), <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_A_Real_American_Hero_(video_game)" title="G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero (video game)">G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Epyx" title="Epyx">Epyx</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Apple_II" title="Apple II">Apple II</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Commodore_64" title="Commodore 64">Commodore 64</a> (1985), <i><a href="/wiki/Action_Force_(video_game)" title="Action Force (video game)">Action Force</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Interactive" title="Virgin Interactive">Virgin Games</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Commodore_64" title="Commodore 64">Commodore 64</a> (1987), a <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_(video_game)" title="G.I. Joe (video game)" class="mw-redirect">G.I. Joe</a></i> video game by <a href="/wiki/Taxan" title="Taxan">Taxan</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_Entertainment_System" title="Nintendo Entertainment System">Nintendo Entertainment System</a> (1991), a <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe_(arcade_game)" title="G.I. Joe (arcade game)">G.I. Joe</a></i> arcade game by <a href="/wiki/Konami" title="Konami">Konami</a> for <a href="/wiki/Arcade_game" title="Arcade game">arcades</a> (1992), and <i><a href="/wiki/G.I._Joe:_The_Atlantis_Factor" title="G.I. Joe: The Atlantis Factor">G.I. Joe: The Atlantis Factor</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Capcom" title="Capcom">Capcom</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_Entertainment_System" title="Nintendo Entertainment System">Nintendo Entertainment System</a> (1992).<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> A new game for <a href="/wiki/Wii" title="Wii">Wii</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xbox_360" title="Xbox 360">Xbox 360</a>, <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_3" title="PlayStation 3">PlayStation 3</a>, <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_2" title="PlayStation 2">PlayStation 2</a>, <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_Portable" title="PlayStation Portable">PSP</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nintendo_DS" title="Nintendo DS">Nintendo DS</a> was released to coincide with the new G.I. Joe film, <i>G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra</i>.</p>
